Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
+1 I like this a lot.

@Parth-Brahmbhatt thanks for the clarification. Is there going to be any documentation the default behavior and possibly giving recommendations for how users should configure the system? And you're also right about the SASL configuration, and it would be nice to say somewhere that the option is available. Kafka users are not necessarily super knowledgeable on the features of ZK.

The website documentation should be updated (http://kafka.apache.org/documentation.html). We have a JIRA for SSL/TLS (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2441), we should probably have one for ZK auth too.
@becketqin Did the commit history get screwed up somehow? This seems to be including a bunch of unrelated stuff.

@ijuma addressed other styling comments as far as testing goes I actually tried adding a unit test based on digest, however the issue is we are on zkClient-0.5 and the APIs to actually getAcl for nodes are not part of this release. Those APIs will be part of the next release whenever it happens. In absence of the getAcl API there is no way for us to verify that correct acls are set. 

@ijuma  and @fpj I will be happy to add the documentation for "Securing kafka zookeeper nodes". Should I just add a wiki page right away? I originally thought it might be better to wait till the final version of PR gets merged and then create the wiki page as wikis seem to be published right away but I could add a wiki page right now and make a bolt RED notice on top to indicate it is still under review. Let me know either ways.

This pull request looks good
@becketqin could you rebase on trunk? There are too many unrelated diff files which makes it very hard to review.

@SinghAsDev Sorry for being late on this, regarding the subscribe semantics I am convinced 1) we do not need to have an extra blacklist pattern in the API but just let users specify that in the regex, and 2) we do not need to do incremental subscription and replacing subscription should just be fine.

Regarding the metadata refresh, what I was thinking is that the current patch took a different scheduled task with different topic sets outside Metadata for regex subscription, while if we can piggy-back it with metadata refresh we can potentially reduce the code complexity while the cost of having metadata refresh always asking for all topics seems OK to me since in practice users would probably want to set the "regex refreshing interval" to be the same as "metadata refreshing interval" the same anyways. What do you think?

On the other hand, we do not necessarily need to make ListTopics API also changing the Metadata states object as @hachikuji suggested since I feel it is in many cases a one-time thing.

I could review this PR again and check it in once it gets rebased / updated.
@guozhangwang @hachikuji Yes.... I must have done something wrong.... I don't know how to fix it. Do you mind if close this PR and open another one?

Is it OK if I cherry-pick that into my branch (you will remain as the author of the change)?
@ijuma You can cherry-pick it or I can also do a PR with this part to keep the link to KAFKA-2072 if you prefer. As you like.
Could someone review this one? May be @gwenshap or @ijuma?
@dajac I am happy either way, so I'll leave it up to you. :) If you create a PR with only that commit, I will review it. We will still need a committer to review it and merge it though.

@becketqin Looks like you may have merged instead of rebasing (there's still the initial commit at the front of the history). You might have to rewind to the initial commit and try the rebase again (maybe someone else knows a better way?). Anyway, if you fix the problem in your local branch, you should be able to do a 'push -f' to update this PR.
@ijuma Ok. I just opened PR (#170) with this part.

One question that I just remembered from Authorizer discussion, should the session have subject instead of Principal ?

Good point @Parth-Brahmbhatt. I totally forgot about that :)

Can you explain in which scenarios will this matter? Also, right now the SSL code exposes a Principal but not a Subject - do we need to change that too?
LGTM

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #228](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/228/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good
Would it make sense to merge this and iterate if needed in the authorizer PR?

The Subject is kind of a wrapper around Principals and can support more use cases. Subject has other things like public/private Credentials  + it can have a list of principals instead of single principal. These things might be helpful in future when we support authentication schemes, For Example sasl with impersonation is one example where we may have 2 principals, the user being impersonated and the impersonating user. 

I guess we can live it as is for now and once we encounter a real use case we can change the type to subject. 

I agree with @ijuma lets merge this in and we can discuss this later.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #229](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/229/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

Just went finish going through the code for first pass. Well structured code. A late comment, in which case would the runtime call Connector.reconfigure() instead of call ConnectorContext.requestTaskReconfiguration()? Also, would it worth having Initializable/Configurable/Startable/Shutdownable interface?
LGTM. As this doesn't change any running code, it's low-risk.
LGTM, @hachikuji could you rebase?

@becketqin `ConnectorContext.requestTaskReconfiguration` is for Connector implementations to call to indicate that some event happened that requires updating the tasks. For example, a JDBC connector would invoke it if it noticed a table was added since that would require work to be redistributed among tasks. `Connector.reconfigure` is called by the framework to update the configuration; for example, if a user submitted a modified connector configuration (say, added another connection URL and credentials to start copying another database, or added a table to the whitelist of tables), then the framework would invoke this to notify the connector of changes. The default implementation just stops and restarts the connector -- you only need to override `reconfigure` if stopping and restarting is too expensive. To be honest, I'm not sure this is valuable -- we may end up wanting to remove this just to keep things simpler, especially since we can add it with the default implementation in a later version if we want to.

On the interfaces, I considered it. The class hierarchy is already a bit more complex than I'd like and I didn't actually have a use for those interfaces. Since added `implements` to a class is backwards compatible, I figured it's better to only add them once we see a use for them. The only drawback to not adding them now is that if we end up with inconsistent method signatures we won't be able to add the interfaces in the future.
Thanks @becketqin @hachikuji , I left some comments on the ticket regarding the names. Other than that the implementation LGTM.

@guozhangwang @hachikuji makes sense. Will update. However, for this to happen we need to somehow make networkClient aware of the fact that if pattern subscription is being used get metadata for all topics. There are a few ways I could think of for doing this.
1. Have Metadata object maintain a flag that indicates wether we need metadata for all topics or just for the ones maintained in metadata.
2. Have NetworkClient maintain a flag which is set by KafkaConsumer during subscribe(pattern) and unsubscribed during unsubscribe(pattern). This will require changing the KafkaClient interface though.

I am more inclined towards Option 1. What do you guys suggest?
@SinghAsDev Option 1 definitely sounds nicer to me.

@SinghAsDev Btw, I was planning to use a MetadataListener in KAFKA-2464 to hook into metadata updates: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/165/files#diff-62bba39339405475f71241a182ef9819R229. Seems like that might be sufficient for this case too.
@hachikuji yea, it will be needed. Should I wait for your patch to go in?
@SinghAsDev Nah, yours is probably easier to get through, so go ahead. I'll rebase accordingly.
@guozhangwang The build failure appears to be unrelated. The two test failures are tracked in KAFKA-2442 and KAFKA-2455.
+1 on option 1 also.

This pull request looks good
For the file connector, and as a simple example, do we want to add a StringConverter?

Debatable, I think, for a few reasons.
1. I think it's bad to use raw types anyway since it gives you few options for updating the schema if you ever need to.
2. Would StringConverter support anything besides String? We could have it convert the primitive types to Strings, which wouldn't be too bad, but the complex types would require a new serialization format. I don't really want to encourage Converter implementations that only have partial support for the API.
3. I was thinking we might want to also improve the file connector so it can demonstrate more complex data. For example, we could report a struct that included extra information like line number (maybe only added if a config flag is set).

1. Just copying log lines to Kafka is a valid use-case that can enjoy some simplicity. Note that we have String and Int serializers in o.a.k.common, so clearly we acknowledge that these are a thing.
2. I see your point about partial support. I thought we do want to support simple cases that don't require everything we provide.
3. Is it just for educational value? because I prefer the default connector example to be as simple as humanly possible.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #245](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/245/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@gwenshap Fair point about directly copying logs in as plain strings -- totally reasonable. However, I encountered an interesting problem -- both using Strings and when I turn on schema-less mode in the JsonConverter. Both will fail the system test if it's switched to use those Converters.

The reason is offsets. The offsets use the same key and value converters as regular data. Which means with a StringConverter, they will always be converted to Strings, which is not very helpful when you try to reload them...

One obvious choice is to add separate settings for offset serializer and deserializer. That may not be that bad, I had that previously and only removed it to reduce the number of required configs. However, it is also a bit odd to have to use multiple types of converters, and with some you'll just get random errors from connectors, e.g. this one from the test I mentioned:

```
org.apache.kafka.copycat.errors.CopycatException: Unexpected offset schema.
    at org.apache.kafka.copycat.file.FileStreamSourceTask.poll(FileStreamSourceTask.java:72)
    at org.apache.kafka.copycat.runtime.WorkerSourceTask$WorkerSourceTaskThread.execute(WorkerSourceTask.java:292)
    at org.apache.kafka.copycat.util.ShutdownableThread.run(ShutdownableThread.java:82)
```

This one is caught in a sane way because I explicitly verified the schema of the offset returned by the lookup in the FileStreamSourceTask:

```
                    if (!offsetWithSchema.schema().equals(OFFSET_VALUE_SCHEMA))
                        throw new CopycatException("Unexpected offset schema.");
                    Long lastRecordedOffset = (Long) offsetWithSchema.value();
```

But if I hadn't you would have just gotten a ClassCastException (which is the error that left a bunch of people confused about why serialization wasn't working when they were using the default serializer incorrectly and for which we added special error handling code to clarify in the new producer).

Not sure what the best solution is here. We could:
1. Add the `offset.key.converter` and `offset.value.converter` settings and not provide defaults. Users have to understand that they need to configure all of these, but that at least provides an opportunity to point out pitfalls since they'll need to read some docs about the settings and we can add notes in the sample configs.
2. Add the settings back and default to the `key.converter` and `value.converter` settings. This makes it easier in some cases, but error prone if they want to use non-schema-preserving converters. The user needs to understand the details of how capable different converters are or they are likely to end up with buggy configurations.
3. Do something with annotations/extra methods on converter classes so there is a way to check whether they have the necessary support. Annotations seem cleaner, but I don't know that it's sufficient because the JsonConverter can operate in both schema and schema-less modes. However, at least in schema-less mode it is better than StringConverter at preserving types -- connectors could potentially work around the missing schemas by assuming null schemas match and then catch any exceptions caused by mismatching types.

Another related issue is that if you need to configure any of these differently and they have settings with the same name, you are currently unable to because we just pass the worker configs directly to all the converters.
This updated version looks good to me, but I don't have a linux box handy to test on and don't think I have anything to test on that would support nested virtualization.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #246](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/246/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

Just to keep readers of this thread in the loop, the approach we decided on offline is to separate out the configuration, make it default to using a format that we can guarantee serializes/deserializes with good fidelity, indicate that the setting is low importance and shouldn't be changed without great care. The offset commit API will change a bit. The framework will handle ensuring we maintain sufficient information about the writer schema for offsets that, given a list of schemas to use for reading, we are able to properly deserialize and return the data. This requires connectors to be careful about maintaining compatibility between versions, but this isn't new -- they always would have had to support multiple offset schemas if they change the format. The new solution just makes this more explicit in the APIs.
